courseDescription: This course addresses the social, political, psychological, economic, and international dimensions of leadership through a social science framework.  A specific focus is given to the dynamic interactions between social structures and leadership behavior.  Students explore how society shapes leaders and how leaders shape society.  Using an introspective approach, students consider their role as current and future leaders in a diverse society.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in analyzing societal structures
Evaluation of leadership behavior impact on society
Introspective analysis of leadership role in a diverse society
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding social, political, psychological, economic, and international dimensions of leadership
Navigating dynamic interactions between social structures and leadership behavior
Self-reflection on personal leadership style and impact on society

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the intersections between maritime leadership, technology, and society. It will explain the important elements of the marine transportation and technological systems, which consist of waterways and ports that allow for various modes of transportation to move people and goods to, from, and on the water. Specific topics include an introduction to different types of cargo, how cargo is moved, ship types, ship equipment, ship routes, basic navigation and ship stability, emerging industries including offshore wind and autonomous systems, maritime law, maritime safety, and leadership.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of ship types and equipment
Familiarity with autonomous systems in maritime industry
Understanding maritime law and safety regulations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication with team members and stakeholders
Collaboration with diverse groups in the maritime sector
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in ship stability and navigation issues
Analyzing emerging industries like offshore wind for maritime applications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Decision-making in maritime operations
Team coordination in various maritime settings
Leading safety initiatives in maritime environments

courseDescription: This class uses leadership theory and research to introduce students to leadership principles and practices related to the management, supervision, and governance of public safety agencies.  Attention is given to the way that leadership in public safety (law enforcement, homeland security, emergency management, information security, and fire and rescue) agencies is distinct from leadership in private companies and businesses.  Specific attention is given to the ethical, social, political, economic, and technological dimensions of public safety leadership.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of technological dimensions in public safety leadership
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse stakeholders in public safety agencies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of information related to public safety
Analyzing ethical dilemmas in leadership decisions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervision and governance of public safety agencies
Applying leadership theory in public safety contexts

courseDescription: AWS Academy Cloud Foundations is intended for students who seek an overall understanding of cloud computing concepts, independent of specific technical roles. It provides a detailed overview of cloud concepts, AWS core services, security, architecture, pricing, and support.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying security vulnerabilities in the cloud
Organizational and Leadership Skills: N/A

courseDescription: An opportunity to integrate service and applied learning experience with leadership perspectives.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Service leadership
Applied learning leadership

courseDescription: The study of selected topics which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule.
Technical and Digital Skills: Specialized technical skills based on selected topics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with experts in the field
Presenting complex information in a clear and concise manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing innovative solutions to unique problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing specialized projects
Leading a team with diverse expertise
Adapting to changing requirements and technologies

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for independent study
Setting and achieving study goals

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation skills for sharing study outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for independent study
Setting study goals and milestones
Taking initiative in research direction

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with a basic introduction to leadership, with a focus on leadership history, leadership styles, traits, and skills. The differences between managers and leaders will be explored.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership styles understanding
Traits of effective leaders
Management vs leadership comparison
Leadership history knowledge

courseTitle: Red Hat Linux System Administrator I
courseDescription: The first of two courses covering the core system administration tasks needed to manage Red Hat Enterprise Linux servers  Red Hat System Administration I is designed for IT professionals without previous Linux system administration experience. The course provides students with Linux administration competence by focusing on core administration tasks. This course also provides a foundation for students who plan to become full-time Linux system administrators by introducing key command-line concepts and enterprise-level tools.  This course is the first of a two-course series that takes a computer professional without Linux system administration knowledge to become a fully capable Linux administrator.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of Linux system information
Organizational and Leadership Skills: N/A

courseTitle: Red Hat Linux System Administrator II
courseDescription: Red Hat System Administration II is the second part of the RHCSA training track for IT professionals who have already attended Red Hat System Administration I. The course goes deeper into core Linux system administration skills in storage configuration and management, installation and deployment of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, management of security features such as SELinux, control of recurring system tasks, management of the boot process and troubleshooting, basic system tuning, and command-line automation and productivity. This course assumes that students have attended Red Hat System Administration I.
Technical and Digital Skills: Installation and deployment of Red Hat Enterprise Linux
Management of security features such as SELinux
Management of the boot process and troubleshooting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: N/A

courseDescription: This course tackles two major cyber law subjects.  The first part of the course examines various U.S. laws and legal considerations that impact the digital and cyberspace worlds from traditional civil, and to a lesser extent, traditional criminal perspectives.  The second part will familiarize cyber operations professionals about the extent of and limitations on their authorities to ensure operations in cyberspace are in compliance with U.S. law, regulations, directives and policies.  The course will also introduce students to miscellaneous cybersecurity topics such as the Federal Acquisition Requirements.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of legal considerations in digital and cyberspace
Familiarity with U.S. law, regulations, directives, and policies in cyberspace operations
Awareness of Federal Acquisition Requirements in cybersecurity
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of laws on cyber operations
Critical evaluation of legal implications in cyberspace
Identifying limitations on authorities in cyberspace
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading compliance efforts in cyber operations
Organizing legal documentation for operations
Managing adherence to U.S. laws in cybersecurity

courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the concepts and complexity of leadership in a globalized society and provide the opportunity to put leadership theory into practice.  Emphasis will be on the development of the student as a leader who thinks globally, appreciates cultural diversity, is technologically savvy, knows how to build partnerships and alliances, and has the capacity to share leadership.  Students will also evaluate their current mindset and leadership skills and create a professional plan for development as a global leader.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of technology for global leadership
Data analysis for decision-making in a global context
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conflict resolution in a global setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of global leadership strategies
Identifying and addressing global leadership challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating a professional development plan as a global leader
Sharing leadership responsibilities in a diverse environment
Building alliances to achieve global goals

courseDescription: This course focuses on the study of contemporary leadership theory and practice, with particular emphasis on public and non-profit sectors. The critical themes of ethics and cultural competence are woven throughout the course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ethical leadership in public and non-profit sectors
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in diverse cultural contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and addressing cultural biases in organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading diverse teams with cultural sensitivity
Implementing inclusive leadership practices in public and non-profit sectors

courseDescription: This course examines how ethical principles can be used to guide effective leadership practices.  Students will gain an understanding of how ethical principles in the workplace have developed over time. They will also explore the connections between individual ethics and workplace behaviors, in addition to leadership strategies that promote ethical behavior by workers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ethical principles in leadership
Application of ethical principles in the workplace
Analysis of workplace ethics development over time
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Connecting individual ethics to workplace behaviors
Promoting ethical behavior through leadership strategies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of ethical dilemmas in leadership
Identifying connections between ethics and effective leadership practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing ethical principles in leadership decisions
Creating a culture of ethics within an organization

courseDescription: This course addresses leadership in public, private, and non-profit organizations relative to laws that impact such organizations. Students will examine their role as leaders within legal systems that influence business operations such as employment law, intellectual property, antitrust, white collar crime, and bankruptcy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of white collar crime laws
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic decision-making within legal constraints
Leading legal compliance initiatives
Managing legal teams effectively

courseDescription: Design thinking is a human-centered approach to problem solving and innovation. With design thinking one can confidently generate solutions to problems in organizations or to launching a new product or enterprise. It is being used by leaders for developing meaningful and useful responses to contemporary challenges.  In this course, an overview of design thinking is provided, along with a model containing key questions and tools to help leaders understand design thinking as a problem solving approach.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Utilization of key design thinking questions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementation of design thinking in organizational settings
Development of meaningful responses to challenges
Leading teams in applying design thinking principles

courseDescription: This course examines gender differences in leadership, including communication styles, leadership style, and experiences in business environments. Students will explore media and cultural representations of women in leadership, as well as women leaders in popular industries. Personal leadership development and skills will be explored from the perspective of advancing women in leadership roles.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of gender differences in leadership
Analysis of media and cultural representations of women leaders
Utilization of technology for leadership development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of gender disparities in leadership
Identifying and addressing challenges faced by women leaders
Strategic decision-making for advancing women in leadership roles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Personal leadership development strategies
Team building and collaboration in diverse settings
Empowering and mentoring other women leaders

courseDescription: This course is focused on examining and expanding on the application of leadership principles and decision making. It is designed to have students step out of their comfort zones and look at leadership issues from various sides. The course will provide background and learning on primary leadership concepts with ethics ideals sprinkled within the content. Students will be challenged to find articles and examples for leadership application in multiple business, industry, government, and societal realms, taking on both protagonist and antagonist roles in the examination of the issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching and analyzing leadership articles and examples
Utilizing online resources for leadership application
Utilizing digital tools for research and presentation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in discussions from multiple perspectives
Facilitating group discussions on leadership issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of leadership principles and decisions
Identifying ethical implications in leadership scenarios
Analyzing leadership issues in various contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking on leadership roles in group discussions
Managing conflicting viewpoints in leadership debates
Applying leadership concepts in real-world scenarios

courseDescription: This course explores technology as it relates to leadership experiences. Theories, case studies and real world examples are analyzed to show both successful and unsuccessful uses of online and digital approaches that inform leaders' communication strategies.  Students will explore how their own digital identities may impact their futures as leaders. They will also learn how to create digital identities that will shape their professional identities throughout their careers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding digital technologies impact on leadership
Utilizing online approaches for communication strategies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Analyzing case studies and real-world examples
Adapting communication strategies based on digital experiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying successful and unsuccessful uses of technology in leadership
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Shaping professional identities through digital presence
Exploring the impact of digital identities on leadership futures

courseDescription: This course is designed to help students enhance their personal and professional development through innovation guided by faculty members and professionals.  This course offers students an opportunity to integrate disciplinary theory and knowledge through developing a nonprofit program, product, business, or other initiative. The real-world experiences that entrepreneurships provide will help students understand how academic knowledge leads to transformations, innovations, and solutions to different types of problems.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management
Team coordination
Delegating tasks effectively
Adapting to changing business environments

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear and concise reporting of findings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management of specialized research projects
Guiding teams in unexplored areas
Strategic planning for specialized studies

courseDescription: This course explores technology as it relates to leadership experiences. Theories, case studies and real world examples are analyzed to show both successful and unsuccessful uses of online and digital approaches that inform leaders' communication strategies.  Students will explore how their own digital identities may impact their futures as leaders. They will also learn how to create digital identities that will shape their professional identities throughout their careers.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of digital approaches on leadership
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing a personal digital brand
Strategic digital identity creation
Utilizing digital platforms for professional growth
